fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear Algebra Done Right

fr:title.text: A linear operator is diagonalizable iff its eigenvectors form a basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A linear operator is diagonalizable iff its eigenvectors form a basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 11.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator of V. Then L is diagonalizable if and only if there is a basis of V consisting entirely of eigenvectors of L.

Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let (e_{1},…,e_{n}) be an Orthonormal Basis for V. Then for any vector v\in V, we have |\langle v,e_{1}\rangle |^{2}+…+|\langle v,e_{n}\rangle |^{2}\leq \left \lVert v \right \rVert ^{2}.

fr:title.text: Eigenvectors of normal operator are orthogonal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvectors of normal operator are orthogonal
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 11.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a normal linear operator. If \lambda ,\mu \in \mathbb {C} are distinct eigenvalues of L with eigenvectors v and w (respectively), then \langle v,w\rangle =0.

We see that (\lambda -\mu )\langle v,w\rangle =\langle \lambda v,w\rangle -\langle v,\overline {\mu }w\rangle =\langle Tv,w\rangle -\langle v,T^{*}w\rangle but \langle Tv,w\rangle -\langle v,T^{*}w\rangle =0 by definition of adjoint, so (\lambda -\mu )\langle v,w\rangle =0. Since \lambda \neq \mu , this means \langle v,w\rangle =0 as desired.

fr:title.text: Every orthonormal list extends to an orthonormal basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every orthonormal list extends to an orthonormal basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 9.5.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. If e_{1},…,e_{m}\in V are orthonormal vectors, then we may extend them to form an Orthonormal Basis of V.

By the Basis extension theorem, we may extend the vectors to form a basis e_{1},…,e_{m},v_{m+1},…,v_{n} of V. Then using Gram-Schmidt process for inner product spaces, we transform these vectors into an orthonormal basis. But since e_{1},…,e_{m} are already orthonormal, the Gram-Schmidt process leaves them alone.

fr:title.text: Existence of orthonormal basis for finite-dimensional inner product spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of orthonormal basis for finite-dimensional inner product spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 9.5.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Then there exists an Orthonormal Basis for V.

Let n=\dim (V). Since V is finite-dimensional, there exists a set of linearly independent vectors \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} such that V=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{n}) and there is no smaller set of vectors spanning V. Then using the Gram-Schmidt process for inner product spaces, we transform this set into an orthonormal basis of V.

fr:title.text: Gram-Schmidt process for inner product spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Gram-Schmidt process for inner product spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 9.5.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Suppose v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V are linearly independent vectors. Let f_{1}=v_{1}. For k=2,…,m we define f_{k} recursively by f_{k}=v_{k}-\frac {\langle v_{k},f_{1}\rangle }{\langle f_{1},f_{1}\rangle }f_{1}-\dots -\frac {\langle v_{k},f_{k-1}\rangle }{\langle f_{k-1},f_{k-1}\rangle }f_{k-1} For each k=1,…,m, using the Canonical norm, let e_{k} = \frac {f_{k}}{\left \lVert f_{k} \right \rVert } Then e_{1},…,e_{m} form an Orthonormal Basis for \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m}) and moreover \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{k})=\mathrm {span}(e_{1},…,e_{k}) for each k=1,…,m.
(Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.)

fr:title.text: Kernel and image of normal operators

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel and image of normal operators
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 11.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space with a Norm. Let L\colon V\to V be a normal linear operator. Then the following all hold:

fr:title.text: Linear operators on complex vector spaces have an upper-triangular matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear operators on complex vector spaces have an upper-triangular matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 7.5.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then there exists a basis B for V such that M(L) is upper triangular matrix with respect to B.

The basic argument is that we will consider a chain of subspaces U_{1}\subseteq U_{2}\subseteq …\subseteq U_{n-1}\subseteq V where \dim (U_{k})=k for each k=1,…,n-1 and \dim (V)=n. Moreover each U_{k} is invariant under L. Then we just need to find a basis v_{1},…,v_{n} of V such that v_{1},…,v_{k} forms a basis of U_{k}. The Criteria for linear operator to have an upper-triangular matrix implies M(L) with respect to this basis is upper-triangular.

fr:title.text: Operator is normal iff norm of operator equals norm of its adjoint

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Operator is normal iff norm of operator equals norm of its adjoint
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 11.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space with a Norm. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L is normal if and only if \left \lVert Lv \right \rVert =\left \lVert L^{*}v \right \rVert for all v\in V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polar decomposition
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 11.6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is analogous to writing a complex number as z=r\mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta }. Here \mathrm {e}^{\mathrm {i}\theta } is analogous to U, and r is analogous to \sqrt {L^{*}L}.

fr:title.text: Positive operator has unique square root

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positive operator has unique square root
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 11.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L be a Positive operator on V. Then there exists a unique square root of L.
Consequently, we will unambiguously refer to \sqrt {L} for the square root of L when we know L is a positive operator.

Let V, W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear operator. The Singular values of L are the non-negative square roots of the eigenvalues of L^{*}L listed in decreasing order, as many times as the dimension of the corresponding Eigenspace of L^{*}L.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Spectral theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 11.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L is normal if and only if there exists an Orthonormal Basis of V consisting of eigenvectors of L.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume L is normal. Then combining Linear operators on complex vector spaces have an upper-triangular matrix and If a linear operator is upper triangular to some basis, then there is an orthonormal basis which turns it into an upper triangular matrix implies there exists an orthonormal basis B=(e_{1},…,e_{n}) for which the matrix M(L) is upper triangular.
We can repeat this argument to find \left \lVert L^{*}e_{j} \right \rVert ^{2}=\sum ^{n}_{k=1}|a_{j,k}|^{2}=|a_{j,j}|^{2} which implies a_{i,j}=0 for i\neq j, as desired.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume the eigenvectors of L form an orthonormal basis for V. Then M(L) is diagonal with respect to this basis (since each basis vector is an eigenvector). Then M(LL^{*})=M(L)M(L^{*})=M(L^{*})M(L)=M(L^{*}L) which implies LL^{*}=L^{*}L, hence L is normal.
Let V be a complex inner product space. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. We say L is Unitary if \langle Lv,w\rangle = \langle v,L^{-1}w\rangle for all v,w\in V.

fr:title.text: Writing a vector as a linear combination of an orthonormal basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Writing a vector as a linear combination of an orthonormal basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 9.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let (e_{1},…,e_{n}) be an Orthonormal Basis for V. Then for any vector v\in V, we have v = \langle v,e_{1}\rangle e_{1} + … + \langle v,e_{n}\rangle e_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \mathbb {C}^{n} is an inner product space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 9.1.4

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoint of linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be a linear transformation. Then the Adjoint (or Hermitian Conjugate) of L is the operator L^{*}\in \mathcal {L}(W,V) such that \langle L(v),w\rangle =\langle v,L^{*}(w)\rangle for any v,w\in V.
Note: in Physics literature, the adjoint of L is usually written with daggers L^{\dagger } because it's a more cut-throat audience.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cauchy-Scwharz inequality
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 9.3.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let u,v\in V. Then using the Canonical norm we have |\langle u,v\rangle |\leq \left \lVert u \right \rVert \left \lVert v \right \rVert .

fr:title.text: Criteria for linear operator to have an upper-triangular matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for linear operator to have an upper-triangular matrix
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 7.5.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F} with basis v_{1}, …, v_{n}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: The matrix M(L) with respect to (v_{1},…,v_{n}) is an Upper-triangular matrix.
L(v_{k})\in \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{k}) for each k=1,…,n
\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{k}) is invariant under L for each k=1,2,…,n

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Determinant of linear operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.

To prove this is well-defined, we should prove this is independent of choice of basis. If we changed basis to a basis C, then [L]_{C}=M^{B}_{C}[L]_{B}M^{C}_{B} and the determinant of both sides are the same since M^{B}_{C}=(M^{C}_{B})^{-1}, Determinant of inverse is inverse of determinant, and Determinant of product is product of determinants.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Diagonalizable linear operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. We say L is Diagonalizable if the eigenvectors of M(L) form a basis of V. In this case, M(L)=\begin {pmatrix}\lambda _{1} & & & \\ & \lambda _{2} & & \\ & & \ddots & \\ & & & \lambda _{n}\end {pmatrix}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimensional formula
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.5.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. Let W be a (not necessarily finite-dimensional) vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then the following all hold:
\mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (L) is a finite-dimensional subspace of W, and
\dim (V)=\dim (\ker (L))+\dim (\mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (L))
Note: this theorem goes by many names (e.g., Axler calls it "the fundamental theorem of linear maps").

fr:title.text: Direct sum of subspace and orthogonal complement is entire space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of subspace and orthogonal complement is entire space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 9.6.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subspace of V. Then V=U\oplus U^{\perp }.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 7.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} be an eigenvalue of L. Then we define the Eigenspace of L to be V_{\lambda }=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\lambda v\}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Definitions 5.5 and 5.8
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator on V. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {F} is an Eigenvalue of L if there is a non-zero vector u\in V such that L(u)=\lambda u. The vector u is called an Eigenvector of L corresponding to eigenvalue \lambda .
Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Eigenvalues of self-adjoint operator are real

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvalues of self-adjoint operator are real
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 11.1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. Let \lambda \in \mathbb {F} be an eigenvalue of L. Then \lambda \in \mathbb {R}.

fr:title.text: Eigenvectors of distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvectors of distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 7.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}, let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Let \lambda _{1},…,\lambda _{m}\in \mathbb {F} be distinct eigenvalues of L with corresponding nonzero eigenvectors v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V. Then v_{1},…,v_{m} are linearly independent.

fr:title.text: Equivalent conditions to be an eigenvalue

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalent conditions to be an eigenvalue
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 7.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Let \lambda \in \mathbb {F}. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: \lambda is an eigenvalue of L
L-\lambda I is not injective
L-\lambda I is not surjective
L-\lambda I is not invertible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of eigenvalues
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 7.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V\neq \{0\} be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {C}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L has at least one eigenvalue.

Let n=\dim (V), let v\in V be a nonzero vector. We have the collection of vectors \{V, Tv, T^{2}v, …, T^{n}v\} Since this contains n+1 vectors, it must be linearly dependent. Then there exists scalars a_{0},a_{1},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {C} not all zero, such that 0=a_{0}v+a_{1}Lv+a_{2}L^{2}v+…+a_{n}L^{n}v Let m be the largest index such that a_{m}
eq 0 (so all a_{k}=0 for k>m and we can just drop these terms). Since v
eq 0, we must have m>0 (and even possibly m=n). Consider the polynomial p(z)=a_{0}+a_{1}z+…+a_{m}z^{m}. Then using the immediate consequences of the fundamental theorem of algebra, we can factorize p(z) as p(z)=c(z-\lambda _{1})(…)(z-\lambda _{m}) where c,\lambda _{1},…,\lambda _{m}\in \mathbb {C} and c
eq 0.

Then 0=a_{0}v+a_{1}Lv+a_{2}L^{2}v+…+a_{n}L^{n}v=p(L)v and 0=p(L)v=c(L-\lambda _{1}I)(…)(L-\lambda _{m}I)v which means at least one of the factors L-\lambda _{j}I must be non-injective. This means \lambda _{j} must be an eigenvalue of L.

fr:title.text: Image of linear map is a subspace of codomain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Image of linear map is a subspace of codomain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then its image \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (L) is a subspace of W.
Well, since Linear maps take zero to zero, we have established that L(\vec {0}_{V})=\vec {0}_{W}.

Let w\in \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (L) and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then there exists a v\in V such that L(v)=w. We see L(av)=aL(v)=aw which implies aw\in \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (L). Hence the result.

fr:title.text: Injective linear maps between finite-dimensional vector spaces are surjective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Injective linear maps between finite-dimensional vector spaces are surjective
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.7.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V and W be finite-dimensional vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to W. Then the following are equivalent:
L is invertible
L is surjective
L is injective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inner product
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let \mathbb {F} be a subfield of \mathbb {C} (possibly \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}). Let V be a Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. An Inner Product on V is a map \langle -,-\rangle \colon V\times V\to \mathbb {F} such that
Linearity in first slot: for all u,v,w\in V we have \langle u+v,w\rangle =\langle u,w\rangle +\langle v,w\rangle
Positivity: for all v\in V we have \langle v,v\rangle \geq 0
Positive-definiteness: for all v\in V, \langle v,v\rangle =0 iff v=0
Conjugate symmetry: for all u,v\in V we have \langle v,u\rangle =\overline {\langle u,v\rangle }

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inner product space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An Inner Product Space is a vector space V equipped with an Inner product.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inner products for polynomials
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 9.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider \mathbb {C}[z]. We can define several different inner products for \mathbb {C}[z]. Let p(z) and q(z) be polynomials. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: \langle p,q\rangle = \int ^{\infty }_{0}p(z)\overline {q(z)}\mathrm {e}^{-z}\,\mathrm {d} z integrated along the real axis
\langle p,q\rangle = \int _{D}p(z)\overline {q(z)}\,\mathrm {d} z integrated over the unit disc D centered at the origin

fr:title.text: Inner product is antilinear in second slot

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inner product is antilinear in second slot
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 6.6 (d) and (e)
Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 9.1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Then for all u,v,w\in V and for all a\in \mathbb {F}, we have \langle u,v+w\rangle =\langle u,v\rangle +\langle u,w\rangle and \langle u,av\rangle =\overline {a}\langle u,v\rangle

fr:title.text: Inner product with zero vector is zero

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inner product with zero vector is zero
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear Algebra Done Right Theorem 6.6 (b) and (c)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V. Then \langle \vec {0},v\rangle =0 and \langle v,\vec {0}\rangle =0.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Invariant subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 7.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator on V. We call a subspace U\subseteq V Invariant under L if for each u\in U we have L(u)\in U.
That is to say, the image of every vector in U under L remains in U. So L(U)\subseteq U.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic vector spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 6.7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. We say V and W are Isomorphic if there exists a bijective linear transformation L\colon V\to W. We will often write V\cong W to indicate V and W are isomorphic.
In this case, we often call L an Isomorphism.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel of linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 6.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then the Kernel (or "null space") of L is the set \ker (L) of all vectors of V mapped to the zero vector of W by L; i.e., \ker (L)=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}\}

fr:title.text: Kernel is a subspace of the domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel is a subspace of the domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then \ker (L) is a subspace of V.
Claim 1: for any u,v\in \ker (L), we claim (u+v)\in \ker (L). Observe L(u+v)=L(u)+L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}+\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W}, which implies (u+v)\in \ker (L) as desired.
Claim 2: For any a\in \mathbb {F} and v\in \ker (L), we see L(av)=aL(v)=a\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W} by Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector, hence av\in \ker (L).
From these two claims and by Criteria for subset to be a subspace, we have the result.

fr:title.text: Linear maps take zero to zero

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear maps take zero to zero

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map of vector spaces. Then L(\vec {0}_{V})=\vec {0}_{W}.
We see L(\vec {0}_{V})=L(\vec {0}_{V}+\vec {0}_{V})=L(\vec {0}_{V})+L(\vec {0}_{V}) and then adding the inverse of L(\vec {0}_{V}) gives the result.

fr:title.text: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.2.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear map. Then L is injective if and only if \ker (L)=\{\vec {0}\}.
Assume L is injective. We know \vec {0}\in \ker (L). Let v\in \ker (L) be arbitrary. Then L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}=L(\vec {0_{V}}) which implies v=\vec {0}_{V}. Hence \ker (L)=\{\vec {0}_{V}\} as desired.

Now, assume \ker (L)=\{\vec {0}\}. We will show that L is injective Let u,v\in V. Suppose L(u)=L(v). Then \vec {0}_{W}=L(u)-L(v)=L(u-v), so (u-v)\in \ker (L). But by assumption, this means (u-v)\in \{\vec {0}_{V}\}, which implies u-v=\vec {0}_{V}, which means (by adding v to both sides) u=v. Hence L is injective.

fr:title.text: Linear map to lower-dimensional space cannot be injective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map to lower-dimensional space cannot be injective
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 6.5.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F} such that \dim (V)>\dim (W). Then no linear map L\colon V\to W can be injective.

fr:title.text: Linear map to higher-dimensional spaces cannot be surjective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map to higher-dimensional spaces cannot be surjective
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 6.5.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F} such that \dim (V)<\dim (W). Then no linear map L\colon V\to W can be surjective.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of a linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let (e_{1},…,e_{n}) be an ordered basis of V, let (f_{1},…,f_{m}) be an ordered basis of W, let L\colon V\to W be a linear map.
Compare this to the notion in elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Matrix of sum of linear maps

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of sum of linear maps
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let L_{1},L_{2}\colon V\to W be linear maps.
Then the matrix of the sum of linear maps is the matrix sum of respective matrices M(L_{1}+L_{2})=M(L_{1})+M(L_{2}).

fr:title.text: Matrix of a scalar multiple of a linear map

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of a scalar multiple of a linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let L\colon V\to W be a linear map, let a\in \mathbb {F}.
Then the matrix of a scalar multiple of L is a scalar multiple of the matrix, i.e., M(aL)=aM(L).

fr:title.text: Matrix of composition of linear transformations is matrix multiplication

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix of composition of linear transformations is matrix multiplication
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 6.6.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U, V, and W be Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces over \mathbb {F}, let L_{1}\colon U\to V and L_{2}\colon V\to W be linear maps.
Then the matrix of their composition is the matrix multiplication of their respective matrices: M(L_{2}\circ L_{1})=M(L_{2})M(L_{1}).
Let V be an inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Then \left \lVert v \right \rVert =\sqrt {\langle v,v\rangle } is a norm on V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Normal operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say L is Normal if LL^{*}=L^{*}L.

fr:title.text: Operators cannot have more distinct eigenvalues than the dimension of its vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Operators cannot have more distinct eigenvalues than the dimension of its vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 7.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be Finite-Dimensional Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator. Then L has at most \dim (V) distinct eigenvalues.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orthogonal vectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let u,v\in V. We say u,v are Orthogonal (denoted u\bot v) if \langle u,v\rangle =0.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orthogonal vectors are linearly independent
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 9.4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let v_{1},…,v_{n}\in V be Orthogonal vectors. Then v_{1},…,v_{n} are linearly independent.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orthogonal complement
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.6.1

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orthogonal projection
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.6.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subspace of V. Then we define the Orthogonal Projection P_{U} of V onto U uses the fact that every v\in V may be written uniquely as v=u+w where u\in U and w\in U^{\perp }, so P_{U}(v)=u.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orthonormal Basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.4.1 and 9.4.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let B be a basis of V. We say the basis B is Orthonormal if for all e_{i},e_{j}\in B we have \langle e_{i},e_{j}\rangle =\delta _{i,j} is the Kronecker delta \delta _{i,j}=0 for i\neq j and \delta _{i,i}=1.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Parallelogram law
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 9.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let u,v\in V. Then using the Canonical norm we have \left \lVert u+v \right \rVert ^{2}+\left \lVert u-v \right \rVert ^{2}=2(\left \lVert u \right \rVert ^{2}+\left \lVert v \right \rVert ^{2})

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Permutation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. A Permutation \pi of n elements is a bijection from the set \{1,2,…,n\} to itself.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Positive operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.5.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say L is positive if L is self-adjoint L=L^{*}, and also \langle Tv,v\rangle \geq 0 for all v\in V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of orthogonal projection
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 9.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subspace of V. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: P_{U}\in \mathcal {L}(V) is a linear operator of V
For any u\in U, we have P_{U}(u)=u
For any w\in U^{\perp }, we have P_{U}(w)=\vec {0}
For each v\in V we have v-P_{U}(v)\in U^{\perp }
For each v\in V, we have \left \lVert P_{U}(v) \right \rVert \leq \left \lVert v \right \rVert

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of the adjoint
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 11.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L_{1},L_{2}\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be a linear transformation. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: (\lambda L_{1})^{*}=\overline {\lambda }L_{1}^{*} for any \lambda \in \mathbb {F}
(L_{0}L_{1})^{*}=L_{1}^{*}L_{0}^{*} where L_{0}\colon U\to V is a linear map of an inner product space U over \mathbb {F}
I^{*}=I where I is the identity linear transformation
If L_{1} is invertible, then L_{1}^{*} is invertible and (L_{1}^{*})^{-1}=(L_{1}^{-1})^{*}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pythagorean theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 9.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product space over \mathbb {F}. Let u,v\in V. If u\perp v, then using the Canonical norm we have \left \lVert u+v \right \rVert =\left \lVert u \right \rVert +\left \lVert v \right \rVert

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Self-adjoint linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 11.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say L is Self-Adjoint (or Hermitian) if L=L^{*}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sign of a permutation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.11

fr:title.text: Square root of a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Square root of a linear operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 11.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be an Inner product spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let L,R\in \mathcal {L}(V) be a linear operator. We say R is a square root of L if L=R^{2}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric Group of degree n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the Symmetric Group of degree n to be the set S_{n} of all permutations of n elements equipped with Composition of functions since composing two permutations of n elements is another permutation of n elements.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It's not hard to prove this, indeed, forms a Group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Two-line notation for permutations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.2

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Addition of complex numbers as the binary operator + by (a+\mathrm {i} b)+(c+\mathrm {i} d)=(a+c)+\mathrm {i}(b+d)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Addition of linear maps
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let S,T\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be linear transformations from V to W. Then we may define the Sum of S and T to be the linear transformation S+T defined by (S+T)(v)=S(v)+T(v) for all v\in V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Additive inverse is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. For each v\in V, there is a unique additive inverse of v in V.
Suppose w and w' are additive inverses of v. Then w=w+0=w+(v+w')=(w+v)+w'=0+w'=w' which gives us w=w' as desired.
Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. We denote by -v the additive inverse of v\in V.
Similarly, for any v,w\in V, we denote by v-w the expression v+(-w).

fr:title.text: Algebraic properties of composition of linear transformations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic properties of composition of linear transformations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The following hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity: for any T_{1}\in \mathcal {L}(V_{1},V_{2}), T_{2}\in \mathcal {L}(V_{2},V_{3}), T_{3}\in \mathcal {L}(V_{3},V_{4}), we have (T_{1}\circ T_{2})\circ T_{3}=T_{1}\circ (T_{2}\circ T_{3}).
Identity: I\circ T=T and T\circ I=T for any T\in \mathcal {L}(V,W)
Distributivity: (S_{1}+S_{2})\circ T=(S_{1}\circ T)+(S_{2}\circ T) and S\circ (T_{1}+T_{2})=(S\circ T_{1})+(S\circ T_{2}) whenver these are defined.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis of vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V be vectors. We say B=\{v_{1},…,v_{m}\} is a Basis of V if B is linearly independent and \mathrm {span}(B)=V.
Compare this to Basis of Vector Space from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis reduction theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.3.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If V=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m}), then either \{v_{1},…,v_{m}\} forms a basis of V or some v_{i} can be removed to obtain a basis of V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basis extension theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.3.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every linearly independent set in a finite-dimensional vector space V can be extended to a basis of V.

fr:title.text: Composition of linear transformations is a linear transformation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composition of linear transformations is a linear transformation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U, V, W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let S\in \mathcal {L}(U,V) and T\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be linear maps. Then T\circ S\in \mathcal {L}(U,W) is a linear transformation defined by (T\circ S)(u)=T(S(u)) for all u\in U.

fr:title.text: Criteria for subset to be a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for subset to be a subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 4.3.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then U is a subspace of V if the following conditions all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive identity: \vec {0}\in U
Closed under addition: for any u,v\in U, u+v\in U
Closed under scalar multiplication: for any a\in \mathbb {F} and u\in U, we have au\in U

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criterion for direct sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if the only way we can write \vec {0}=u_{1}+u_{2} with u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2} is for u_{1}=u_{2}=\vec {0}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let B be a basis of V. Then the Dimension of V is \dim (V) equal to the cardinality of B. In particular, if V is infinite-dimensional, we just write \dim (V)=\infty .
Compare this to the notion from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Dimension does not depend on choice of basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension does not depend on choice of basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Then every basis B of V has \dim (V)=|B|. In other words, the dimension of a finite-dimensional vector space is well-defined.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dimension of a sum
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Let U\subseteq V and W\subseteq V be subspaces. Then \dim (U+W)=\dim (U)+\dim (W)-\dim (U\cap W)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of spaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space. We call U_{1}+U_{2} the Direct Sum if each element of U_{1}+U_{2} can be written in only one way as a sum u_{1}+u_{2} where u_{1}\in U_{1} and u_{2}\in U_{2}.
In this case, we write U_{1}\oplus U_{2}.

fr:title.text: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of two subspaces intersect in the zero subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.4.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces. Then U_{1}+U_{2} is a direct sum if and only if U_{1}\cap U_{2}=\{\vec {0}\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of basis
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Corollary 5.3.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every finite-dimensional vector space has a basis.

fr:title.text: Field-valued functions form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field-valued functions form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let D\neq \emptyset be any set. Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then the Set of all functions \mathbb {F}^{D} forms a vector space. Vector addition of f,g\in \mathbb {F}^{D} is given by (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) for any x\in D, and scalar multiplication is given by (af)(x)=af(x) for any a\in \mathbb {F}.

There are various related vector spaces of interest to Mathematicians. For example, when \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R} and D\subseteq \mathbb {R}, the set of all continuous real-valued functions on D forms a subspace of \mathbb {R}^{D}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite-Dimensional Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space. If there exists a finite subset S\subseteq V such that \mathrm {span}(S)=V, then we say V is Finite-Dimensional.
If there is no such finite set spanning the entire space, then we say V is Infinite-Dimensional.

fr:title.text: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Extreme Value Theorem

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Algebra via Extreme Value Theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By Modulus of complex polynomial attains a minimum value, we see that |f| attains its minimum value. Let z_{0}\in \mathbb {C} be a point where the minimum is attained. We will show if f(z_{0})\neq 0, then z_{0} is not a minimum (which proves by contrapositive that the minimum of |f(z)| is zero, and therefore f(z_{0})=0).

Let b\in \mathbb {C} be such that b^{k}=-1/a_{k}. There exists a constant c>1 such that if 0<t<1, then |g(tb)|\leq |1+a_{k}t^{k}b^{k}|+t^{k+1}c=1-t^{k}(1-tc) Taking t=1/(2c) in this inequality, we have |g(tb)|<1. But this contradicts the assumption that the minimum of |g(z)| is |g(0)|=1. This contradiction implies the result.

fr:title.text: Length of linearly independent list not greater than length of spanning set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Length of linearly independent list not greater than length of spanning set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.2.9

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space. Suppose that v_{1},…,v_{m} are linearly independent vectors of V, and suppose S\subseteq V be a spanning set \mathrm {span}(S)=V. Then m\leq |S|.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear combination
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 5.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v_{1},…,v_{n}\in V. Then we define a Linear Combination of v_{1}, …, v_{n} to be a_{1}v_{1}+…+a_{n}v_{n} for some a_{1},…,a_{n}\in \mathbb {F}.
Compare this to the notion of Linear combination from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear Dependence Lemma
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 5.2.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V be linearly dependent. If v_{1}\neq 0, then there exists an index j\in \{2,…,m\} such that the following hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: If v_{j} is removed from \{v_{1},…,v_{m}\}, then \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,\hat {v}_{j},…,v_{m})=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m})

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 6.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. A Linear Map from V to W is a function L\colon V\to W such that:
Additive: L(u+v)=L(u)+L(v) for all u,v\in V, and
Homogeneous: L(av)=aL(v) for all a\in \mathbb {F} and v\in V We denote the set of all linear transformations from V to W by \mathcal {L}(V,W).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear map lemma
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be finite-dimensional vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Suppose v_{1},…,v_{n} is a basis of V, and suppose w_{1},…,w_{n} is a basis of W. Then there exists a unique linear map T\colon V\to W such that T(v_{i})=w_{i} for each i=1,…,n.

fr:title.text: Linear maps form a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear maps form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 6.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Then \mathcal {L}(V,W) forms a vector space over \mathbb {F}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linearly Independent Vectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Otherwise, we say v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V are Linearly Dependent.
Compare this to the notion from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modulus of complex number
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. We define the Modulus of z to be the value |z|=\sqrt {x^{2}+y^{2}}>0. In particular, if x\in \mathbb {R}, then |x+\mathrm {i} 0|=\sqrt {x^{2}+0}=|x| is just the absolute value.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplicative inverse of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any nonzero z\in \mathbb {C}, z\neq 0, there exists a unique complex number denoted z^{-1} such that zz^{-1}=1. Moreover, if z=x+\mathrm {i} y with x,y\in \mathbb {R}, then z^{-1}=\frac {x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}+\mathrm {i}\frac {-y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}
Uniqueness: Suppose there are two complex numbers w\in \mathbb {C} and v\in \mathbb {C} such that zv=1 and zw=1. Then v=1v=(zw)v=(wz)v=w(zv)=w1=w.

fr:title.text: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Negating a vector by multiplying by minus one
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V. Then (-1)v=-v.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomials form a vector space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}[z] be the set of all polynomial with coefficients in \mathbb {F} and in unknown z. Then defining (p+q)(z)=p(z)+q(z) and (ap)(z)=ap(z) for any a\in \mathbb {F} and p,q\in \mathbb {F}[z] forms vector addition and scalar multiplication.

fr:title.text: Properties of addition of complex numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of addition of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}+z_{2}=z_{2}+z_{1}
Additive identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 0 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 0+z=z. Moreover, 0=(0,0).
Additive inverse: For each z\in \mathbb {C} there exists a unique complex number denoted -z such that z+(-z)=0. Moreover, if z=(x,y), then -z=(-x,-y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of multiplying complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2},z_{3}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: z_{1}z_{2}=z_{2}z_{1}
Multiplicative identity: There is a unique complex number denoted 1 such that for any z\in \mathbb {C} we have 1z=z. Moreover, 1=(1,0).
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: z_{1}(z_{2}+z_{3})=z_{1}z_{2}+z_{1}z_{3}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.9

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1} and z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: \overline {z_{1}+z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}+\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of the sum is the sum of conjugates)
\overline {z_{1}z_{2}}=\overline {z_{1}}\overline {z_{2}} (the conjugate of products is the product of conjugates)
\overline {1/z_{1}}=1/\overline {z_{1}} when z_{1}\neq 0
\overline {z_{1}}=z_{1} if and only if \Im (z_{1})=0
\Re (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2}(z_{1}+\overline {z_{1}}) and \Im (z_{1})=\frac {1}{2\mathrm {i}}(z_{1}-\overline {z_{1}}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of modulus
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.2.11

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z_{1},z_{2}\in \mathbb {C} be complex numbers. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Triangle inequality: |z_{1}+z_{2}|\leq |z_{1}|+|z_{2}|
z_{1}\overline {z_{1}}=|z_{1}|^{2} which implies when z_{1}\neq 0, z_{1}^{-1}=\frac {\overline {z_{1}}}{|z_{1}|^{2}}

fr:title.text: Properties of bases of finite-dimensional vector spaces and subspaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of bases of finite-dimensional vector spaces and subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 5.4.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional vector space with n=\dim (V). Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Every subspace U\subseteq V has \dim (U)\leq \dim (V).
If V=\mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{n}), then \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} is a basis of V.
If \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} is linearly independent in V, then \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} forms a basis of V.

fr:title.text: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiplication by zero gives zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let v\in V and 0_{F}\in \mathbb {F}. Then 0_{F}v=\vec {0}.
We see by distributivity, 0_{F}v=(0_{F}+0_{F})v=0_{F}v+0_{F}v, and then subtracting 0_{F}v from both sides yields \vec {0}=0_{F}v-0_{F}v=(0_{F}v+0_{F}v)-0_{F}v=0_{F}v as desired.

fr:title.text: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiples of zero vector are the zero vector
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let \vec {0}\in V and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then a\vec {0}=\vec {0}.
We see a\vec {0}=a(\vec {0}+\vec {0})=a\vec {0}+a\vec {0}, then adding the additive inverse of a\vec {0} to both sides yields the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Scalar multiplication of linear maps
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Section 6.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be vector spaces over \mathbb {F}. Let S\in \mathcal {L}(V,W) be a linear transformation from V to W and a\in \mathbb {F}. Then we may define the Scalar multiple aS to be the linear transformation defined by (aS)(v)=aS(v) for all v\in V.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of complex numbers
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics §2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the Set of Complex Numbers \mathbb {C}=\{(x,y)\mid x,y\in \mathbb {R}\}. Given a complex number z=(x,y), we call \Re (z)=x the Real Part of z, and \Im (z)=y the Imaginary Part of z.
We write \mathrm {i}=(0,1) for the Imaginary Unit and write z=(x,y) as z=x+\mathrm {i} y. (Electrical Engineers use j instead for the imaginary unit.)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Span
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the Span of a set of vectors from elementary linear algebra.

fr:title.text: Span is smallest subset containing the supplied vectors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Span is smallest subset containing the supplied vectors
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Lemma 5.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}, let v_{1},…,v_{m}\in V be vectors. Then
v_{j}\in \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m}) for each j, and
for any other subspace U\subseteq V such that v_{j}\in U for each j=1,…,m, we have \mathrm {span}(v_{1},…,v_{m})\subseteq U.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.3.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U\subseteq V be a subset. Then we call U a Subspace of V if U is a vector space over \mathbb {F} under the same operations that make V a vector space over \mathbb {F}.
In particular, V is always a subspace of itself.
Compare this to Subspace of a real vector space from elementary linear algebra.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Let U_{1},U_{2}\subseteq V be subspaces of V. We define the (Subspace) Sum of U_{1} and U_{2} to be the set U_{1}+U_{2}=\{u_{1}+u_{2}\mid u_{1}\in U_{1},u_{2}\in U_{2}\}.
More precisely, this is a subspace of V.
This can be extended to any finite number of subspaces of V.

fr:title.text: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sum of subspaces is smallest subspace containing the summands

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let U_{1},…,U_{m}\subseteq V be subspaces of a vector space V. Then U_{1}+…+U_{m} is the smallest subspace of V containing U_{1}, …, U_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector Space
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 4.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. A Vector Space over \mathbb {F} consists of a set V equipped with vector addition +\colon V\times V\to V and scalar multiplication \cdot \colon \mathbb {F}\times V\to V such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Commutativity: for all u,v\in V, we have u+v=v+u
Associativity: for all u,v,w\in V, we have (u+v)+w=u+(v+w)
Additive identity: there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all v\in V we have v+\vec {0}=v
Additive inverse: for each v\in V there exists a w\in V such that v+w=\vec {0}
Associativity of scalar multiplication: for all v\in V and a,b\in \mathbb {F}, we have (ab)v=a(bv)
Multiplicative identity: The multiplicative unital element 1\in \mathbb {F} is such that for all v\in V we have 1v=v
Distributivity: for all a,b\in \mathbb {F} and u,v\in V we have a(u+v)=au+av and (a+b)v=av+bv

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Compare this to the definition of a Real vector space from elementary linear algebra. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {R}, we call V a real vector space. When \mathbb {F}=\mathbb {C}, we call V a Complex Vector Space.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of sequences
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Example 4.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then \mathbb {F}^{\infty } is the set of all sequences over \mathbb {F}. Then vector addition defined componentwise (u_{k})+(v_{k})=(u_{k}+v_{k}) and scalar multiplication defined componentwise a(u_{n})=(au_{n}) give us a vector space.

fr:title.text: Vector space of polynomials is infinite-dimensional

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector space of polynomials is infinite-dimensional
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 5.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Then the vector space of polynomials \mathbb {F}[z] is an infinite-dimensional vector space.

Let S\subseteq \mathbb {F}[z] be any finite set, let N=\{\deg (p)\mid p\in S\}. Then consider the smallest positive integer n\in \mathbb {N} which is not n\notin N. Then z^{n}\notin \mathrm {span}(S). So \mathbb {F}[z] cannot be finite-dimensional.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Zero vector is unique
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Proposition 4.2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F}. Then the additive identity \vec {0}\in V is unique.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: De Moivre's formula
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Theorem 2.3.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=r(\cos (\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (\theta )) be a complex number in polar form. Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then:

fr:ol.fr:li: The exponentiation z^{n}=r^{n}(\cos (n\theta )+\mathrm {i}\sin (n\theta ));
The n^{\text {th}} roots of z are given by the n complex numbers z_{k}=r^{1/n}[\cos ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)+\mathrm {i}\sin ((\theta +2\pi k)/n)].

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: So we hit the "highpoints" of an elementary introduction to linear algebra (or, an introduction to elementary linear algebra). Intermediate linear algebra should revisit this subject and "distill" it into a "library" of definitions, theorems, and proofs.

Good texts for intermediate linear algebra include Axler's Linear Algebra Done Right, though I learned it from Lankham, Nachtergaele, and Schilling's Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics since this is the textbook for Math 67 at the Math Department of University of California, Davis.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complex conjugation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 2.2.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let z=x+\mathrm {i} y\in \mathbb {C} be a complex number with x,y\in \mathbb {R}. Then we define the Complex Conjugate of z to be the complex number \overline {z}=x-\mathrm {i} y.
